text:
Sawaddee ka welcome to hot thai kitchen today I 
am making something called haw mok which is a spicy

red curry custard with fish now I know that sounds 
good it ought right now but stay with me and you

see this is so so so delicious super easy and it's 
actually been requested many many times so let's

get started so this dish is basically a custard 
and a custard is just a mixture of egg and some

sort of liquid and then cooked and this custard is 
flavored with red curry so that's what I'm going

to start with I've got three tablespoons of red 
curry paste which is a lot it is spicy this dish

is a spicy dish but you can just use too if you 
think this is too spicy and to this I'm just going

to add a little bit of coconut milk just enough 
to break this up if I pour the whole thing in

it'll just slosh around then it'll be impossible 
to get it mixed up okay so now that that's smooth

I can add more of this coconut milk and it'll mix 
in more easily now the rest of it since this is

a custard or any eggs so I've got two large eggs 
beat them first then the egg goes into the custard

and then seasoning some fish sauce again you 
have to taste and adjust the amount of fish sauce

needed because every curry paste has a different 
level of salt now you wondering well how am i

Matthysse this is raw eggs in it when you're done 
with the base you can just put a little bit in a

cup and steam it or microwave it so you can cook 
a little and taste it some sugar to round off the

spiciness and if you're using palm sugar which is 
what I'm using you want to make sure it's chopped

quite fine because otherwise won't dissolve when 
you get big lumps now some extra aromatic kaffir

lime leaves which I finally finally slice and this 
will add sort of a bright citrusy aroma that will

help sort of mask any fishiness that comes from 
the fish and now for the fish there are actually

two ways to do this some people like to take the 
fish and blend it together with the custard and

make a firmer almost like a fish mousse but what 
I like is I like to keep the pieces of the fish

whole so I've got here some barramundi but you 
can use absolutely any kind of fish you like

really anything that you've got on hand you can 
even try it with salmon get it mixed in so the

fish gets a chance to absorb some of that flavor 
and you can also use other kinds of seafood you

can do shrimp mussels and clams without the 
shell are or squid we actually sometimes do

humble calais which is palm up with the mix of 
seafood in it all right that's the base let's

prep our containers normally in Thailand we steam 
home up in a banana leaf container sometimes we

make a cup out of it sometimes we wrap it in this 
present and for convenience sake though I'm going

to use a ramekin however the banana leaves are not 
just for containers when you steam food in banana

leaves it infuses that sort of woodsy force the 
aroma into the food as well so in order to mimic

that what I've done is I've got some banana leaves 
which you can get in the frozen section of Asian

groceries love the smell the important thing 
is you got to clean it banana leaves are dirty

they've got chalky dusty stuff so you got to take 
a white paper or towel and give it a good wipe I'm

going to line my container with them shiny side 
up there's always a dull side and a shiny side so

this is a little too fat it's really easy to trim 
banana leaves this way see the grain banana leaves

have a have a grain and you just tear it off and 
pull it comes off really really easily this way

though you have to cut okay so that fits well and 
I'm going to take another strip and line it this

way that's my container and you know what this is 
the first time I've actually done this normally I

too lazy I just do it in a ramekin with nothing 
in it but this is for a special occasion okay so

I've got my containers ready to go so the bottom 
of Hummel is always a bed of vegetables and that

vegetable can be a variety of things but one 
of the common ones is cabbage so I've got some

shredded cabbage here which I have steamed and 
I just steamed this in the microwave make sure

there's a little bit of water on it and the reason 
why I steamed it is so that it settles nicely at

the bottom otherwise it's just sticking up all 
over the place and its really annoying I've done

it before and what I like though is add a little 
bit of kale in Thailand we use this vegetable

called bye y'all and it's impossible to find here 
and it's a dark green vegetable stir dee leaves

just like kale just to kind of mimic bhaiyaa I'm 
gonna use scale also steamed so I'm going to do

both cabbage and kale and it's up to you really 
how much vegetables you want to put in all right

basil Thai basil also goes on the bottom and as it 
cooks it will infuse that and sweet floral aroma

into the custard Thai basil and red curry always 
go together fill the cup starting with the fish

always sir before you later because the 
curry paste likes to fall to the bottom

press it down to get rid of any air bubbles 
which is not a big deal and just being a little

excessive I've got my handy dandy steamer 
here medium heat I don't want it too high

because otherwise it will pop up a lot and not 
be smooth but unlike my steamed egg it doesn't

have to be super low because there's just so 
much going on curry paste fish and all that

stuff that it doesn't have to be super super 
smooth so about 15 to 20 minutes so the way to

tell these are done is first of all they're going 
to be quite puffed up from they were before and

I like to do a quick jiggle careful it's hot but 
it just like do a quick jiggle and you see how it

just doesn't really it doesn't jiggle that much 
it's quite firm and you can always just poke it

in with a little knife and see there's liquid 
coming out and but I think that's pretty good

yeah there's a very classic garnish that goes 
on top of home oven of course it's all optional

at this one you could go ahead and eat them if 
you want but if you want to look a little nicer

what I've got here is just some thickened coconut 
milk it is just coconut milk that I cooked with a

little bit of cornstarch you can do rice flour or 
even all-purpose flour anything that will make it

kind of this consistency and then I'm going to top 
the custard and it just adds a little creaminess

but more importantly it will be a canvas for our 
final garnish and the final garnish spiritually

or you can also do just julienne red bell pepper 
and you can do extra julienne kaffir lime leaves

which is really common or I just like to do a 
little leaf of cilantro and there you go that

is how look now this is not something you just 
didn't eat a bowl on its own it's strong spicy

stuff you always always serve this with rice the 
texture is so tender practically melt in my mouth

and you really smell that fear lime leaves the 
banana leaf and the Thai basil cut the same time

it's super it's spicy its strong definitely 
kicks your senses you can also do tiny tiny

little ones and little teacups and make it like a 
little appetizer you for parties where you've got

lots of people there as well so do give this 
a try if you've never had savory custard this

will change your world and when you do send me a 
photo Facebook Twitter or Instagram the recipe as

always is on top Thai kitchen comb and I will 
see you next time for your next delicious Thai
